Posts.Title: I have found a lump bubblygirl georgie430

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2009 08:15PM MBCR wrote: Try to stay calm & don't panic yet. I was diagnosed @ 49 after something came up on my yearly mammo. I have 4 kids (24,22,20 & 15). I waited until all my testing & surgical consult & plans were made before I told them. Your kids are not young & the "C" word does not sit well w/ them because evryone thinks its a "death sentence". Once I had definitive info to give them they bonded together & researched stuff together, talked together to get through it. Then they asked me a lot of questions on how I was feeling physically & emotionally. Wait before you tell your kids but talk to other people as you wait for results : your husband, sibling, best friend. It's an emotional time for everyone. Hang in there & LOL.
Posts.Title: I have found a lump bubblygirl georgie430

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2009 07:07PM MBCR wrote: Good Luck!  My prayers are w/ you.The waiting & unknown is the worst. I just started radiation (1 week) & I should be done by the beginning of July.

Posts.Title: RADIATION FATIGUE - POLL bluejay1 Siciliana

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2009 08:41PM MBCR wrote: I am about 1 month after rads & i am still very tired. I sleep 9-10 hours a night & don't always feel rested when I wake up. I go to the gym 3-4 days a week to help bring my energy level up. I hate waking up w/ a tired feeling. It takes me so much longer to get motivated each day.
Posts.Title: RADIATION FATIGUE - POLL bluejay1 Siciliana

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2009 07:59PM MBCR wrote: I know when you're tired, working out is tough. But try to take a little walk & add on to that. Believe me, you will see a difference in your energy level. You just have to do it. Go up & down your steps in your house 3-4x in a row. I used to walk to the hospital for my rads ( about a half mile there & then a half mile back). I'm 2 months out of rads now & still fell fatigued, but, it is getting better. I try to go to the gym 2-3 days a week. My daughter started going w/ me. It helps to have a work out buddy.

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2010 09:32AM MBCR wrote: I had a similar scenario. I went for my yearly mammo last Jan & was called back for a re-do, then an ultrasound & 3 ultrasounds later I had a biopsy in March wh/ was positive.It was Stage 1 & I had a lumpectomy in April & radiation. The waiting is the pits, but each step gets a little easier as you get more info. I'm waiting again for the result of another biopsy. At my yearly GYN check up, my GYN did an ultrasound & found a small mass on my uterus, plus my uterine lining was very thick. She is trying to reassure me that it is probably from the Tamoxifen. I had a D&C & biopsy on Thursday & now I'm waiting again.
Posts.Title: The Waiting is the Worst... hopeful01 MBCR

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2010 08:58AM MBCR wrote: Irishmom: I had a lumpectomy & clear nodes.On my first vist w/ the oncologist, she talked about all the different treatment options. She did a blood test for my oncotype score. I had a low score(14), so chemo was not part of my plan I had radiation for 5 weeks & now I am taking Tamoxifen.  It ttok about 2 weeks for the results. PS: I am premenopausal.

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2010 09:05AM MBCR wrote: Cyndie: After seeing the breast surgeon & having all scenarios presented to me, it was not hard to decide.Lumpectomy it was. However, he did tell me that there is a possibility that I may need more than a lumpectomy, depending on my margins, lymph nodes etc...once he actually saws the breast tissue. But it was made very clear that I was going into surgery for a lumpectomy ONLY so I wouldn't wake up w/ any surprises. Read the consent form- be sure the procedure is very clear. There is no family history.
